officialLinks.name: Fee Schedules for Excess Special Baggage (PDF)
Passengers with Hearing/Visual Impairment (Service dogs in cabin)

sourceDates.note: Page shows a notice: 'Starting February 1, 2025, we will temporarily suspend the transportation of dogs … on flights to the United States.' No explicit last-updated date shown.
Header reads 'Air China special baggage charges … 1 Jun 2019 Edition.' File is hosted under a 2026 directory.
No explicit last-updated date shown; referenced for service dog cabin policy.

policyFindings: Regular pets are transported only as checked baggage; service dogs may be brought into the cabin per the disability assistance policy.

Temporary U.S. embargo: Starting February 1, 2025, Air China temporarily suspends transportation of dogs (including guide/hearing dogs) on flights to the United States; affected bookings may change or refund.
Only domesticated cats and dogs are accepted.

Brachycephalic (snub-nosed) and aggressive or harm-risk breeds are not accepted; examples include Boston Terrier, Boxer, Bulldog, Spaniels, Mastiffs, Pugs, Pit Bull–type breeds; and cat breeds such as Burmese, Himalayan, Persian, Exotic Shorthair.
Not accepted: pets that are pregnant, under 8 weeks old, nursing, within 7 days post-partum, or sick.
Limit: one pet per passenger; maximum 32 kg per pet including carrier, food, and water.
Check-in deadline: present the pet at least 120 minutes before departure and sign a liability waiver on the baggage tag.
Booking/approval: apply when making the reservation; carriage only after Air China approval; no interline pet transport; pets not accepted on wet-leased flights.
Operational limits: pets must be carried only in cargo holds with oxygen supply; some aircraft (A319, A320, 737-8 MAX, ARJ21-700) cannot transport pets.
Liability: Air China disclaims liability for illness, injury, or death not related to Air China.

Crate requirements: rigid container (fiberglass, metal, rigid plastic, welded mesh, hardwood); no fiberglass/hard-plastic doors; welded metal lockable door; spacer bars/handles required; ventilation holes on three sides in the upper third with total ventilation area at least 16% and openings covered by wire mesh; solid floor with absorbent bedding (no straw); solid roof; fixed water container refillable from outside; food container fixed/attached; crate must allow the animal to stand, turn, and lie naturally; contact Air China in advance to confirm hold door size/capacity for the specific aircraft.
Fees for small animals (special baggage) charged per container by actual weight (international piece concept): 2–8 kg = USD 600; >8–23 kg = USD 800; >23–32 kg = USD 1,200 (per 1 Jun 2019 Edition).

Documents/quarantine: AQSIQ quarantine certificate required for domestic travel; for international/regional travel, comply with entry/exit/transit country rules; for entry into China, follow microchip, rabies vaccination, designated port, and possible 30‑day quarantine/exemption requirements.
Service dogs: may travel in the cabin with advance request and required documents; when transported in the cargo compartment, general carrier, weight, and other requirements apply.
notes: No operator notes were provided; nothing to reconcile.
Scope: Only airchina.us sources were used; links to other Air China domains were excluded per allowlist.
Some Air China US pages were blocked by site protection, so findings rely on the accessible 'Pets as Checked Baggage' page and the fee PDF.
Practical note: Aircraft hold door sizes and equipment vary; certain aircraft cannot accept pets—contact Air China in advance to confirm crate fit and flight eligibility.

draft.PetPolicySummary: General: Air China accepts only domesticated cats and dogs, and they are transported as checked baggage (no regular pets in the passenger cabin). Temporary U.S. Dog Embargo: Starting February 1, 2025, Air China temporarily suspends transportation of dogs—including guide and hearing dogs—on flights to the United States. Non-acceptance: Aggressive/harm-risk breeds and snub-nosed (brachycephalic) breeds are not accepted. Not accepted: pregnant pets, pets under 8 weeks old, nursing pets, pets within 7 days post-partum, or sick animals. Aircraft restrictions: Pets cannot be carried on aircraft without oxygen-equipped cargo compartments, including A319, A320, 737-8 MAX, ARJ21-700. Booking/limits: Pre-approval required at reservation; one pet per passenger; maximum 32 kg total including container/food/water. Check-in at least 120 minutes before departure; passenger must sign the liability waiver. Documents: Domestic China flights require AQSIQ quarantine certificates. International/regional travel must comply with entry/exit/transit country rules; dogs entering the U.S. must meet CDC requirements. Entry into China: Follow quarantine regulations (ISO 11784/11785 microchip, valid quarantine and rabies vaccination certificates; designated ports; on-site inspection; possible 30‑day quarantine with exemptions). Carrier requirements: Rigid, airline-acceptable crate with adequate ventilation (≥16% wall area; three sides in upper third), welded metal lockable door, solid floor/roof, fixed water container refillable from outside, and space for the pet to stand/turn/lie naturally. Fees: Charged as special baggage by actual weight per the 1 Jun 2019 edition—2–8 kg: USD 600; >8–23 kg: USD 800; >23–32 kg: USD 1,200 (confirm current rates with Air China). Service dogs: May travel in-cabin if requirements are met; when transported in cargo, general pet carriage rules apply. Note: U.S. dog embargo from Feb 1, 2025 applies to service dogs on U.S.-bound flights.
draft.ImprovedPetPolicySummary:
Air China Pet Policy (Summary)

  • Only domesticated cats and dogs accepted; regular pets are carried as checked baggage (no pets in cabin).
  • Temporary U.S. dog embargo: From 2025-02-01, transportation of dogs (including guide/hearing dogs) is suspended on flights to the United States.
  • Not accepted: aggressive/harm-risk breeds and snub-nosed breeds; pets that are pregnant, <8 weeks old, nursing, within 7 days post-partum, or sick.
  • Aircraft limits: No pet transport on A319, A320, 737-8 MAX, ARJ21-700 (no oxygen in some cargo holds).
  • Booking/limits: Pre-approval at reservation; one pet per passenger; max 32 kg including container/food/water; check-in ≥120 minutes; sign liability waiver.
  • Documents: Domestic China: AQSIQ quarantine certificate. International/regional: comply with entry/exit/transit rules; dogs to U.S. must meet CDC rules.
  • Entry into China: ISO 11784/11785 microchip; valid quarantine and rabies vaccination certificates; designated ports; on-site inspection; possible 30‑day quarantine with exemptions.
  • Crate: Rigid, airline-acceptable; ventilation on three sides (≥16% wall area); welded metal lockable door; solid floor/roof; fixed water container refillable from outside; pet must stand/turn/lie naturally.
  • Fees (1 Jun 2019 edition): 2–8 kg: USD 600; >8–23 kg: USD 800; >23–32 kg: USD 1,200. Confirm current rates.
  • Service dogs: Allowed in-cabin when requirements are met; embargo applies to U.S.-bound flights from 2025-02-01.

See: Pets as Checked Baggage and Special Baggage Fees on airchina.us; contact Air China to confirm aircraft acceptance and current charges.
draft.inCompartmentDetails: Regular pets (cats/dogs) are not accepted in the passenger cabin. Only trained service dogs accompanying passengers with disabilities may travel in-cabin on eligible routes. Note: Effective 2025-02-01, transportation of dogs (including guide/hearing dogs) is temporarily suspended on flights to the United States.
draft.inCargoDetails: Only cats and dogs accepted as checked baggage. Pre-approval required when booking; one pet per passenger; max 32 kg including container/food/water; present at check-in ≥120 minutes before departure and sign liability waiver. No interline transport; aircraft without oxygen-equipped cargo holds (A319, A320, 737-8 MAX, ARJ21-700) cannot carry pets. Crates must meet structural and ventilation standards.
draft.carrierCompartmentDetails:
Compartment Carrier Details

Not accepted: Cats and dogs that are pregnant, under 8 weeks old, nursing, have given birth within 7 days, or are sick.
China quarantine requirements

Based on Announcement No. 5 [2019] of the General Administration of Customs of China.

  • Only cats or dogs (including service dogs) allowed. One pet per person.
  • Must provide valid quarantine certificates and rabies vaccination certificates from official agencies.
  • Pets must have ISO 11784/11785 compliant microchips (15-digit numeric code). - If not compliant, owner must provide their own compatible reader.
  • Pets must undergo 30-day quarantine at designated China Customs facilities unless exempt (see below).
Exemptions from 30-day quarantine
  • Designated countries/territories: Pets from 19 specific regions (e.g., New Zealand, Australia, UK, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, Macau, etc.) → If microchipped and pass on-site quarantine.
  • Non-designated countries: Allowed if microchipped, pass on-site quarantine, and provide a valid rabies antibody test (≥ 0.5 IU/ml, from an approved lab).
  • Guide dogs, hearing dogs, search/rescue dogs: Allowed if microchipped, pass on-site quarantine, and owner presents valid user + training certificates.
Pet container requirements
  • Pets requiring quarantine must arrive through ports equipped with quarantine facilities.
  • The General Administration of Customs of China publishes an updated list of such ports on its official website.
draft.carrierCargoDetails:
In Cargo Carrier Details

Aircraft limits: Pets cannot be transported in cargo on A319 / A320 / 737-8 MAX / ARJ21-700 (no oxygen supply in some cargo holds).
Key rules
  • One pet may be checked per passenger.
  • Max weight: 32 kg (70 lb) total including carrier, food, and water.
  • Check-in deadline: Arrive and complete pet check-in ≥ 120 minutes before departure.
  • You must sign a liability waiver on the back of the baggage tag at check-in.
  • No interline service: Not available with other airlines.
  • Customs notice: If entry rules are not met, pets may be repatriated or destroyed by Customs; the airline is not liable.
Pet carrier requirements
  • Use an air-travel approved carrier, secured properly. For detachable roofs, all latches, nuts, bolts must be present and intact.
  • Door security: Add an extra external lock (e.g., cable tie/clip) that does not harm the pet.
  • Carrier must be acceptable to Air China; non-compliant carriers will be refused.
Prohibited carrier features (not accepted):
  • Fiberglass or hard plastic doors.
  • Openings/holes large enough for paws or nose to protrude.
  • Roof doors or ventilation holes at the bottom ends of side walls.
  • Side openings/vents adjacent to the main door that are not covered with wire mesh.
Dimensions
  • Contact Air China in advance to confirm carrier fits aircraft door and hold capacity.
  • Carrier must allow the pet to stand, turn around, and lie down naturally.
Materials
  • Allowed: fiberglass, metal, rigid plastic, welded mesh, hardwood.
  • Not suitable: containers made entirely of welded mesh or wire solder.
Ventilation
  • Holes in the upper third of the walls on three sides (excluding the door).
  • At least 16% of total wall surface area must be ventilation.
  • Extra holes may be added on the top/sides as needed.
  • All openings must be wire-mesh covered to prevent paws/nose from extending out.
Doors & handling
  • Door forms one end of the container and must have a sliding chain or hinge lock.
  • Doors must be welded metal, strong enough to resist bending/damage.
  • Plastic-shell carriers: door must have ≥ 1.6 cm top/bottom protuberances for hinges/locking pins.
  • Spacer bars/handles should be fitted along the mid-outer walls on both sides for handling and protection.
Floors
  • Solid floor to prevent leakage; provide absorbent bedding (no straw).
Roofs
  • Solid roof; ventilation across the roof is allowed if it does not reduce structural integrity.
Food & water
  • Carrier must have a fixed water container that can be refilled from outside without opening the door.
  • Feed containers must be fixed inside or firmly attached; you may attach food externally for possible delays.

draft.brachycephalicBreedList: Dogs: Affenpischer,  Pekingese, Pug (all breeds),  Shar Pei,  Shih Tzu,  Japanese Dog,  Lhasa Apso,  Tibetan Spaniel,  Chow Chow,  English Little Spaniel,  English Bulldog,  French Bulldog,  Boston Terrier, Boxer,  Brussels Griffon,  Bullmastiff,  British Mastiff Cats: Birman,  Exotic, Persian,  Himalayan,  Burmese,  Scottish Fold,  British Shorthair
draft.serviceAnimalDetails:
Service Animals (In-Cabin & Support)

Starting February 1, 2025, Air China will temporarily suspend the transportation of dogs, including guide and hearing dogs traveling with disabled passengers, on flights to the United States.

Service dogs are specially trained to assist disabled individuals, including guide dogs and hearing dogs. Emotional comfort dogs are not considered service dogs and must follow small animal transport rules.

  • Passengers with visual or auditory disabilities traveling with service dogs in-cabin must be at least 16 years old.
  • Service dogs must have the following certificates presented at ticket purchase and travel:
    • Valid official quarantine certificates, rabies vaccination certificates, and professional training certificates issued by the departure, transit, or destination country.
    • Valid microchips when entering China or on international/regional transit domestic flights.
  • Passengers should verify quarantine regulations of entry-exit countries in advance to ensure compliance.
  • If a dog transport booking to the U.S. was made before the suspension, ticket changes or refunds are available.
  • Reservations for service dogs must be made through Air China ticket offices or authorized agents at least 48 hours before departure.

Check-in

  • Arrive at the check-in counter with the service dog at least 120 minutes before departure.
  • No additional fees apply for service dogs meeting boarding requirements.
  • If checked, service dogs travel free of charge with container and food; their weight does not count toward baggage allowance.
  • Disabled passengers with service dogs cannot occupy emergency exit seats or upper cabin seats on Boeing B747 aircraft.
  • Terminal assistance is provided for disabled passengers with service dogs unless restricted by local authorities.

In-flight Service

  • Support is provided to disabled passengers traveling alone with service dogs as much as possible.
  • Assistance with eating, toileting, excretory functions on seats, or medical services is not provided.
  • Service dogs must wear a work shirt and towing rope during boarding; mouthpieces may be waived with passenger consent.
  • Service dogs must not occupy seats, run freely, or disturb other passengers.
  • Passengers are responsible for their service dog's excretion and maintaining cabin hygiene.
  • Passengers bear liability for any injury or damage caused by their service dogs.
  • There are limits on the number of disabled passengers with service dogs per aircraft; early booking is advised.
Air China may refuse transport of service dogs if:
  • The dog poses a direct threat to health or safety of others.
  • The dog causes serious interference in the cabin or airport.
  • Transport violates government regulations or requirements.
Written explanations will be provided within 10 days if transport is refused.
